journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Edgewise compressive performance of repaired composite sandwich panels – Experiment and finite element analysis

article-meta.aff: 1School of Aeronautic Science and Engineering, Beihang University, Beijing, China
2Composite Manufacturing Center, Commercial Aircraft Corporation of China, Ltd, Shanghai, China

author-notes.corresp: Zhidong Guan, School of Aeronautic Science and Engineering, Beihang University, XueYuan Road No. 37, HaiDian District, Beijing, 0086-100191, China. Email: liu_buaa@yahoo.com.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Bonded repair was conducted to composite sandwich panels with one side skin and full-depth core penetrated damage. Experiments on edgewise compressive behavior of repaired panel were carried out and influences of various repair parameters including different repair materials (high or medium temperature cured pre-preg), different taper ratios for scarf repair (1/30 or 1/10) and different repair techniques (scarf or step repair) were compared. Based on continuum damage mechanics, a three-dimensional finite element model was developed and a good agreement of experimental results with numerical predictions was obtained. With the analysis model, ultimate loads, damage evolution processes and adhesive stress distributions of repaired sandwich panels were investigated. The results of this study have provided an insight into the mechanical performance of repaired sandwich panels under edgewise compressive load, which could lead to improved design and analysis methodologies on the bonded repair of composite sandwich structures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The use of advanced composite materials has been increasing in aeronautical industry for its excellent characteristics of specific strength and stiffness. However, damages are inevitable for composite structures during the whole service life of aircraft, so it is becoming important to develop proper repair techniques that can restore the load-carrying capacities of damaged structures efficiently. Repair on sandwich panels, a main type of composite structure, has been studied extensively these years.

Two different repair methodologies exist, bolted repair and bonded repair. In structural repair manual (SRM) published by main aircraft manufactures, dominant status has been occupied by bonded repair.1,2 In 1980s, experimental studies was employed to investigate the mechanical behaviors of repaired structures,3,4 which established the foundation of bonded repair technique. In composite structures when high-strength recovery is needed, or flush repair surface is required to satisfy the aerodynamic requirements, a bonded scarf or step repair is often used.5 In recent years, considerable studies have been conducted on bonded scarf or step repair of laminated structures. Mechanical performances of a series of scarf-repaired laminate structures had been evaluated6,7 to find out the influences of different repair variables. The results of test could provide meaningful guidance on repair design of composite structure. With the development of numerical technique, finite element method was introduced to analyze load capacity of repaired structures. A parametric finite element model had been developed by Gunnion and Herszberg8 to study the effect of various parameters on the performance of scarf repair. Detailed results on adhesive stress distribution were obtained, which may lead to improved scarf repair design and analysis techniques. A typical scarf repair had been used in highly strained region of F/A-18 horizontal stabilator by Baker et al.9 successfully, and a comprehensive investigation on repaired structures had been conducted by mechanical test and finite element analysis. After thorough study, an improved design methodology for scarf repair was presented by Wang and Gunnion,10 the improved methodology was strain-based, and experimental results confirmed that the new approach could provide a more accurate prediction of repair efficiency. To achieve scarf repair on relatively thick laminate, two “hard-patch” repair methods were investigated by Whittingham et al.11 Micrographic studies were used to verify the rationality of the new repair methods.

As for composite sandwich panels, experimental and numerical studies were presented by Avery and Sankar12 and Hansen13 to investigate the edgewise compressive behavior of sandwich panel with initial delamination defect. The conclusions of their work provided instructions on allowable damage limits of sandwich panels. Wang et al.14 performed an experimental evaluation of sandwich panels repaired by different methods. The influences on stiffness and strength of sandwich panels induced by repair were compared thoroughly. To study the fracture mechanics of repaired sandwich panel, bilinear interface elements were adopted by Chen15 in numerical model to simulate adhesive in repaired structures. Compared with traditional methods, this new approach could predict the failure load, crack path and the residual stiffness in the fracture process of the repaired structure efficiently. The behavior of repaired sandwich beams loaded in four-point bending was investigated by Mahdi et al.16,17 Both experiment and finite element analysis were conducted to study the effects of different repair methods and process parameters. A broad study into bonded repair variables of sandwich structures was performed by Tomblin et al.18,19 and damage tolerance analysis on sandwich structures was also included. Based on this work, an engineering methodology on damage tolerance design of sandwich structures was summarized.

Bonded repair on sandwich panels with one side skin and full-depth core penetrated damage is studied in the paper, and edgewise compressive performance of repaired panels are tested. Within ABAQUS, a three-dimensional (3D) progressive damage finite element model is developed. Using the numerical model, ultimate load, damage evolution process and stress distributions in adhesive are investigated. Good agreement is observed between tests and calculations. Conclusions obtained in the research can provide instructions on bonded repair design of composite sandwich structures.

sec.title: Specimens
sec.p: The ply sequence of repaired sandwich specimens used in the research is [45°/0°/−45°/90°]/C/[45°/0°/−45°/90°], with a dimension of 220 mm × 160 mm. The skin of the sandwich panel was fabricated with the MTM44-1/HTS(12K) pre-preg, and the thickness of each ply was 0.125 mm. The honeycomb core material was HRH-10-1/8-3.0, with a thickness of 10 mm. The adhesive film and core-splice adhesive used in repair were PL7000 and FM490A, respectively.

The initial damage of sandwich panel was one side skin and full-depth core penetrated. Φ25 mm holes were drilled in the center of the sandwich panels to simulate damages. Bonded scarf repair was adopted in the research to repair the damaged panel, and hot-bonder was used to cure the repair region. The schematic diagram of initial damage and repair technique are shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Initial damage and repair technique of sandwich panel. (a) Initial damage, (b) Repair technique

In order to study the influence of repair materials, two types of specimens with different repair materials were employed in the research. The repair material was the same as the parent skin for the first type of specimen (A-1), which was cured at 177℃. The second type was repaired with CYCOM7714A/HTA40(12K) pre-preg, and the ply thickness was 0.158 mm (A-2). CYCOM7714A/HTA40(12K) was a medium temperature-cured pre-preg and the repair region was cured at 121℃ for specimens repaired by CYCOM material. Besides, mismatch would happen between the parent plies and the repair plies due to the thickness differences of these two materials.

Different repair parameters were also considered in the research. Repair parameters include taper ratio and sanding methods. For the taper ratio, specimens with a taper ratio of 1/10 were tested (A-3); for the sanding method, step sanded specimens were introduced (A-4). For this kind of repair, step laps were established between parent plies and repair plies, and the diameters of sanded region were the same for step repair and scarf taper repair. These two repair techniques are compared in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Comparison between scarf taper repair and step repair.

sec.title: Test results
sec.p:
During the tests, repaired specimens were subject to edgewise compressive loads on WDW-200E materials testing machine, and the crosshead loading rate was set to 1.0 mm/min. Test fixtures are shown in Figure 3. In order to avoid failure caused by panel buckling, four-column standing bars were placed at the edge of the sandwich panel. Figure 3.
Test fixtures for sandwich panel edgewise compression.

A total of six categories of specimens were tested in the study, and the test results are listed in Table 1. In the table, symbol “Intact” denotes sandwich panel without any damage; symbol “A-0” denotes damaged sandwich panel; symbol “A-1–A-4” denote repaired sandwich panels with different variables. The detail information (Including cure temperature of repair, sanded type and taper ratio) of each repair specimen has been listed in columns 3 to 5. Table 1.
Test results for sandwich panels.
Specimen Specimen numbers Repair cure temperature Sanded type Taper ratio Ultimate load/KN C.V./% Strength recovery/%
Intact 3 —— —— —— 81.92 7.26 100.00
A-0 3 —— —— —— 45.94 3.83 56.08
A-1 6 High Scarf 1:30 73.51 3.15 89.73
A-2 6 Medium Scarf 1:30 76.09 6.04 92.88
A-3 6 High Scarf 1:10 75.72 2.22 92.43
A-4 6 High Step 1:30 77.70 3.61 94.85

As shown in Table 1, damaged sandwich panels have the lowest compressive ultimate loads due to the high stress concentration at the edge of the damage hole, whereas much higher ultimate loads could be obtained after repair. Compared with the intact sandwich panel, the compressive strength recoveries of repaired specimens are all above 89%, indicating the repair methods conducted in the study could restore the mechanical performance of damaged sandwich panels efficiently. From coefficient of variation listed in the table, six categories are all in allowable range (<10%), therefore the test results are valid for engineering usage.

During experiment, different failure modes of sandwich panels were observed. For intact and damaged but not repaired panels, the fracture occurred in the middle of panel; for repaired panels, the initial damage hole was enhanced by repair patches, therefore critical location transferred from middle of panel to the edge region of repair patches, where the discontinuousness of repaired structure was relatively severe. The failure pictures of repair panel are shown in Figure 4. Figure 4.
Failure mode of repaired panels.

sec.title: Establishment of 3D model
sec.p: To study the edgewise compressive behaviors of repaired sandwich panels, 3D finite element models were established based on software ABAQUS. The dimensions and ply sequences of numerical model were the same as test specimens described in the “Experiment” section of the paper. To avoid the convergence problems after damage occurrence, the ABAQUS/EXPILICT solver was used in the study, and the progressive damage process was implemented by coding VUSDFLD, the subroutine of ABAQUS. The validity of numerical model could be verified by experimental results.

Three-dimensional solid elements were adopted to simulate every single composite layer in the skin of sandwich panels. Elements types were eight-node hexahedral element (C3D8) and six-node triangular prism element (C3D6). The six-node triangular prism elements were used to mesh the tips of scarf sanded region only. Mechanical properties of composite materials used in the model are listed in Table 2. Table 2.
Mechanical properties of composite materials.20,21
MTM Pre-preg T = 0.125 mm E11/GPa E22/GPa E33/GPa G12/GPa G23/GPa G13/GPa ν12 ν13 ν13
141.0 7.8 7.8 3.6 3.6 3.6 0.3 0.3 0.3
XT/MPa XC/MPa YT/MPa YC/MPa ZT/MPa ZC/MPa S12/MPa S23/MPa S13/MPa
2341.0 1450.0 57.8 226.0 80.0 150.0 113.0 113.0 113.0
CYCOM Pre-preg T = 0.158 mm E11/GPa E22/GPa E33/GPa G12/GPa G23/GPa G13/GPa ν12 ν13 ν13
137.6 8.6 8.6 3.5 3.5 3.5 0.3 0.3 0.3
XT/MPa XC/MPa YT/MPa YC/MPa ZT/MPa ZC/MPa S12/MPa S23/MPa S13/MPa
1540.0 925.0 61.0 222.0 80.0 150.0 90.0 90.0 90.0
(1) Only in-plane properties were provided in material sheets.
(2) In analysis model, assuming: E22 = E33, G12 = G23 = G13, ν12 = ν23 = ν13, S12 = S23 = S13.
(3) Strength parameters in 3-direction were empirical data.

In Table 2, t is the ply thickness of pre-preg; Eii (i = 1, 2, 3) is the Young’s modulus in i direction; Gij (i,j = 1, 2, 3) is the shear modulus in i-j plane; νij (i,j = 1, 2, 3) is the Poisson’s ratio in i-j plane; XT/XC, YT/YC and ZT/ZC are the tensile/compressive strengths in 1, 2 and 3 direction, respectively; Sij (i,j = 1, 2, 3) is the shear strength i-j plane.

Assuming the NOMEX honeycomb core, as shown in Figure 5, can endure external loads only in three directions: Compressive loads in T direction and shear loads in LT and WT planes. The honeycomb core was established as a whole cubic bulk in the finite element model. C3D8 elements were also used for honeycomb core, which has five layers of elements in the thickness direction. Core-splice adhesive was considered an isotropic material in the model, and its element type is C3D8 too; eight-node 3D cohesive element (COH3D8) was adopted to simulate adhesive film in repaired structures. Mechanical properties of core, slice adhesive and adhesive film are listed in Table 3. Figure 5.
Geometry of honeycomb core.
Table 3.
Properties of honeycomb core and adhesive film.22-25
HRH-10-1/8-3.0 Honeycomb ETT/MPa GLT/MPa GWT/MPa XTT/MPa SLT/MPa SWT/MPa
138.0 41.4 24.1 2.1 1.2 0.7
FM490A Core-splice adhesive E/MPa G/MPa ν XMises/MPa
1000.0 385.0 0.3 2.5
PL7000 Adhesive film E/MPa G/MPa ν tn0 = ts0 = tt0/MPa GnC = GsC = GtC/(N/mm)
1000.0 385.0 0.3 35.0 4.5
Strength for core-splice adhesive, interfacial strength and critical strain energy for adhesive film were empirical data.

In Table 3, ETT, GLT and GWT are elastic properties for honeycomb core, while XTT, SLT and SWT are its strengths; ti0 (i = n, s, t) and Gi (i = n, s, t) are the interfacial strength and critical strain energy release rate of adhesive film in i direction, respectively; XMises is the failure strength of core-splice adhesive.

In order to simulate the boundary conditions correctly, the four-column standing bars in fixtures were also built in finite element model, and rigid body properties were assigned during analysis. To simulate the support provided by standing bars, general contact properties were added between standing bars and outer surfaces of sandwich skin. Clamping conditions were applied on the fixed end of the panel, and a displacement load was applied on the free end. Besides, out-of-plane displacements were restricted for the surfaces blocked by the fixture. The boundary conditions and the mesh of the finite element model are shown in Figure 6. Figure 6.
Boundary conditions and mesh of finite element model.

sec.title: Failure criteria and damage evolution law
Composite materials
sec.p:
Three-dimensional Hashin criterion25 was adopted to predict the failure of composite layers. Stress-based formulas were used to judge the damage initiation in each layer. Fiber failure, matrix failure and delamination could be governed separately by different formulas in the criterion. The Hashin criterion is presented as follows:
Fiber failure: (1)FT12={(σ11XT)2+(τ12S12)2+(τ13S13)2=1 (σ11>0)(σ11XC)2=1 (σ11<0)
Matrix failure: (2)FT12={(σ11XT)2+(τ12S12)2+(τ13S13)2=1 (σ11>0)(σ11XC)2=1 (σ11<0)
Delamination failure: (3)FT32={(σ33ZT)2+(τ13S13)2+(τ23S23)2=1 (σ33>0)(σ33ZC)2+(τ13S13)2+(τ23S23)2=1 (σ33<0)
The subscripts 1, 2 and 3 denote three principle material directions, respectively. FT1, FT2 and FT3 are the values of the criteria, assuming failure initiates in relevant damage mode once any of them exceeds 1.0.

If failure is detected in a particular composite layer, the properties of materials must be adjusted according to a material property degradation model. To simulate the progressive damage process of composite materials more accurately, damage parameters are introduced to the stiffness matrix of composite materials in the study, and this theory has been utilized widely to implement property degradation for composite materials.26-29
The 3D constitutive equation of undamaged composite materials is shown as: (4)σ=C0:ɛ where

ε=[ɛ11ɛ22ɛ33ɛ12ɛ13ɛ23]T, σ=[σ11σ22σ33σ12σ13σ23]T and C0 is the initial elastic matrix, defined as: C0=[C110C120C130000C120C220C230000C130C230C330000000C440000000C550000000C660] To describe the damages in material principle directions, a symmetric second orders tensor D is introduced, whose eigenvalues di (i = 1, 2, 3) represent the effective reduction in load-carrying area on plane, which is perpendicular to i principal direction. The range of di must be in 0 ≤ di ≤ 1, when di = 0, no damage is occurred in i direction, while di = 1 corresponds a complete damage in i direction. After damage occurrence, the effective stress can be defined as: (5)∧σ=((I-D)-1:σ:(I-D)-T)=M(D):σ
In equation (5), superscript “^” represents effective stress/strain and M(D) is a symmetric forth orders tensor defined as: (6)FT12={(σ11XT)2+(τ12S12)2+(τ13S13)2=1 (σ11>0)(σ11XC)2=1 (σ11<0)
Based on the strain energy equivalence principle, the stain energy for the material without damage can be expressed as follows: (7)We=12σ:ɛ=12 ∧σ:ɛ∧
Equations (8) and (9) can be obtained by combining equation (7) and constitutive equations together: (8)We=12σ:ɛ=12σ:C-1:σ (9)We=12 ∧σ:ɛ∧=12 ∧σ:(Cd)-1:∧σ
In equation (9), Cd represents damaged elastic matrix of composite materials, and equation (10) is given with equations (5) and (9): (10)We=12σ:MT:(Cd)-1:M:σ
So the damaged elastic matrix of composite materials can be expressed in equation (11): (11)Cd=M-1:C:MT,-1

Therefore, constitutive equation of damaged composite materials changed as follows: (12)σ=Cd:ɛ In finite element model, the eigenvalues of damage tensor D are set to constant for composite materials. Once fiber damage, matrix damage or delamination occurs, di (i = 1, 2, 3) = 0.999. The material properties degradation is implemented by coding the subroutine VUSDFLD in ABAQUS.30

sec.title: Honeycomb core and core-splice adhesive
sec.p: Beasant criterion31 is used to predict the failure behavior of honeycomb core: (13)FCore2=(σTTXTT)2+(τLTSLT)2+(τWTSWT)2 where XTT, SLT and SWT are the corresponding strengths in loading directions.
For core-splice adhesive, Mises criterion32 is used: (14)FSplice2=(σMisesXMises)2 where σMises and XMises are the Mises stress and the corresponding strength.
Like method discussed in section 4.1 of the paper, the damaged elastic matrix of honeycomb core and core-splice adhesive can be expressed as: (15)CCore/Spliced=(1-dCore/Splice)CCore/Splice
When damages occur, set dCore/Splice to 0.999.

sec.title: Adhesive film
sec.p:
Cohesive elements are introduced to model the adhesive film in repaired panels, which can predict damage onset and propagation in adhesive film efficiently. As shown in Figure 7, a bi-linear traction–separation law is used to describe the damage behavior of cohesive element during analysis, and the initial linear elastic constitutive relationship of cohesive elements is defined as: (16){tntstt}=[KnnKssKtt]{ɛnɛsɛt} where tn, ts and tt are the normal and the two shear tractions, respectively, and Kii (i = n,s,t), ɛi (i = n,s,t) represent the stiffness component and strain in i direction, respectively. Figure 7.
Bilinear constitutive model of cohesive element.

A quadratic nominal stress criterion is used to predict the damage initiation in adhesive damage: (17)Cd=[C11(1-d1)C12(1-d1)(1-d2)C13(1-d1)(1-d3)000C12(1-d1)(1-d2)C22(1-d2)C23(1-d2)(1-d3)000C13(1-d1)(1-d3)C23(1-d2)(1-d3)C33(1-d3)000000C44(1-d1)(1-d2)000000C55(1-d1)(1-d3)000000C66(1-d2)(1-d3)] where ti0 (i = n,s,t) is the strength in i direction. The Macaulay bracket 〈·〉 implies that compressive normal stress does not contribute to damage initiation.

The damage propagation of adhesive film is determined by B-K law, which is based on the energy release rates: (18)GnC+(GsC-GnC){Gs+GtGn+Gs+Gt}2=GC where Gi (i = n,s,t) is the calculated strain energy release rate in i direction, and GiC (i = n,s) is critical strain energy release rate defined before analysis.

After damage initiates, a linear degradation law based on damage variable D is adopted: (19){Knn=(1-D)Knn0Kss=(1-D)Kss0Ktt=(1-D)Ktt0D={0δ<δ0δmax(δ-δ0)δ(δmax-δ0)δ0≤δ≤δmax1δmax<δ where δ0 is the effective displacement at the initiation of damage, which can be determined through initial stiffness and strength properties, and δmax refers to the maximum value of the effective displacement attained during the whole loading history.

sec.title: Stiffness and ultimate load
sec.p:
The numerical results were compared with experimental results. In Figure 8, the load-displacement curve of intact panel obtained from the experiment is shown. Figure 8(a) shows the experimental load-displacement curves, and Figure 8(b) compares the curves obtained by calculation and experiment. The curve of intact panel is involved in both Figure 8(a) and (b). Based on it, the relationship between calculation and experiment can be established. In Figure 8(a), good agreement observed between curves implies that different repair parameters could hardly affect the edgewise compressive stiffness of sandwich panels. Besides, good agreements can also be observed in Figure 8(b), indicating that the finite element model can simulate the edgewise compressive stiffness of sandwich panel correctly. Figure 8.
Load-displacement curve of different specimens. (a) Experiment, (b) Experiment and calculation.

In Figure 9, ultimate loads are compared between calculation and test. As shown in the figure, the predicted ultimate loads agree well with the experimental results, with a maximum error of 11.0%. Typical failure modes between calculation and test are presented in Figure 10. It can be seen that the calculated damage morphology (totally damaged elements are displayed in red color) is similar to the test. Therefore, the validity of progressive damage mode model on stiffness, ultimate load and failure mode are supported by experimental results. Figure 9.
Ultimate edgewise compressive loads of different specimens.
Figure 10.
Damage morphologies of different specimens.

sec.title: Damage progression
sec.p:
During the test, most compressive loads are carried by 0° plies in skins of sandwich panel, and fiber failure is the dominant failure mode in 0° plies. In Figure 11, the progressive damage processes of different repaired panel are compared through the fiber damage progressions in 0° plies of the corresponding specimens. As shown in the figure, the loads at fiber damage onset vary for different panels. Figure 11.
Fiber damage propagation in repair side 0°plies. (a) Fiber damage in 0° ply at 54KN (b) Fiber damage in 0° ply at 62KN (c) Fiber damage in 0° ply at 64KN (d) Fiber damage in 0° ply at 66KN and (e) Fiber damage in 0° ply at ultimate load, respectively.

At the load level of 54 KN, fiber damage in 0° ply of A-3 specimen is observed. This specimen is repaired with a taper ratio of 1/10, hence the slope of sanded region is relatively steep and severe stress concentration is induced at the edge of the damage hole. With compressive load increasing, fiber damage onsets in 0° ply of A-4, A-2 and A-1 specimens are observed at the load levels of 62 KN, 64 KN and 66 KN, respectively. In Figure 11(e), the fiber damage maps in 0° ply at the maximum load of each specimen are presented. It can be seen that fiber damage propagations have reached the free edge of the panel at the maximum loads, and the load-carrying capacities of 0° ply are lost at the moment which cause the precipitous decline in load-displacement curves.

In Figure 11, it can be seen that fiber damages of all the specimens are initiated at the edge of the damage hole, but differences are exhibited in damage progressions. For A-1, A-2 and A-3 specimens, the fiber damages propagate along the axis perpendicular to the direction of the applied load continuously; for A-2 specimen, no obvious propagation is observed after fiber damage initiation, however, when the compressive load is increased to the level of 66 KN, considerable fiber damages occur out of the taper region, and propagate to the free edge of the panel rapidly. The reason for this phenomenon is that a thicker pre-preg, CYCOM7714A/HTA40(12K), is used as repair plies for A-2 specimens, therefore, a higher load-carrying capacity is achieved in repair plies, and the stress level of 0° ply becomes relatively low in taper region, which causes the discontinuity in fiber damage progression of A-2 specimen.

No relationship was found between the load at 0° ply fiber damage initiation and the load at ultimate failure of sandwich panel. Take A-4 specimen as an example, the initial load on fiber damage of A-4 specimen is relatively low, while the damage propagation rate is slow. As shown in Figure 11(e), A-4 specimen exhibits the smallest fiber damage area in 0° ply at the maximum load. Therefore, the ultimate compressive load of A-4 specimen is the highest among all the repaired panels, which can achieve the level of 77.53 KN.

sec.title: Stress distributions in adhesive
sec.p: Adhesive film is the most important part in boned repair. Calculating the stress distributions along bond-line correctly is the key point on load-carrying capacity prediction of repaired structures. For repaired sandwich panels in this paper, shear and peel stresses are the principal stress components in adhesive, hence the stress distributions discussed in the paper refer to the shear and peel stresses distributions along bond-line.

In order to obtain more accurate results, a fine mesh must be used. However, the calculation cost will be quite high if the analysis is implemented by fine meshed 3D models. Therefore, a quasi 3D thin-slice joints modeling methodology is adopted in the research, with the quasi 3D model, parametric analysis on adhesive stress can be applied efficiently. The establishment of “thin-slice” joint is shown in Figure 12. First, a section plane of joint is created, and then swept the section plane for a short distance (0.125 mm) along the width direction of the joint to establish a quasi 3D model. Although 3D modeling procedure is followed, the width of model is neglectable compared with length and height, so the thin-slice model is named as “quasi 3D.” With the model, 3D solid element is available and the orientations of ±45° plies can be assigned conveniently. Figure 12.
Establishment of quasi three-dimensional (3D) joint model.

Cohesive element is substituted by 8-node hexahedral element (C3D8) in the joint model. In order to output the shear and peel stress distributions along the bond-line, nodes in the center line of adhesive are extracted as the result nodes, and a local coordinate system is established as shown in Figure 13. After stress transformation, the peel stress is taken perpendicular to the scarf bond-line (σ2), and the shear stress is taken in 1–2 plane (τ12). The 1-direction in local coordinate system can denote the relative distance of result nodes along the bond-line, 0 and 1 represent the start point and the end point of the bond-line, respectively. Figure 13.
Result nodes and local coordinate system for adhesive (display skin only).

To check the validation of quasi 3D simplification, A-1 specimen is selected to compare the adhesive distributions obtained by different models. A 1-mm displacement-load is applied on both joint and 3D model, and local coordinate system is made on 3D model along the loading direction to extract shear and peel stress in adhesive.

The calculated stress distributions are shown in Figure 14. Identical trend is observed in the results of both joint and 3D models. In the figure, it can be seen that the adhesive stresses vary significantly along the bond-line and local stress peaks occur at the place where adhesive and 0° ply converge. The explanation is the in-plane stiffness of composite skin varies in the thickness direction, while the stiffness of adhesive film is constant along the bond-line. Therefore, high stress concentration would occur adjacent to the end of 0° ply.8,10 This result supports the validity of the quasi 3D joint model, and smoother curves are available for high mesh density is adopted in the joint model. Figure 14.
Stress distributions along adhesive bond-line for joint model and three-dimensional (3D) model.

Based on the quasi 3D joint model, parametric study is performed on different repaired specimens. To analyze conveniently, A-1 specimen is set as the baseline. The results are shown in Figure 15. Figure 15.
Stress distributions and peak values for different repair specimens. (a) A-1 and A-2 (b) A-1 and A-3 (c) A-1 and A-4 (d) Peak stresses.

In Figure 15(a), the influence of repair materials on stress distribution is presented. Changes can be seen in the trends and peak values of both shear and peel stresses when a different repair material is adopted (A-2 specimen). The thickness of alternative repair ply varies, which induces the mismatch between parent plies and repair plies as illustrated in Figure 16. The relative position of 0° ply in repair patch transfers towards the outer side of the panels, hence the peaks of shear and peel stresses move to the end point of adhesive. Comparing the peak stress values shown in Figure 15(d), although the shape of distribution changes, there is little change to the peak shear and peel stresses. The result indicates that the loading-capacity of adhesive could hardly change for CYCOM pre-preg repair, but the critical location in adhesive transfers to the end of bond-line. Figure 16.
Repair plies for A-1 and A-2 specimens. (a) A-1: High temperature cured (b) A-2: Medium temperature cured.

In Figure 15(b), the influence of taper ratio on stress distribution is investigated. It can be seen that the stress distribution is very sensitive to the taper ratio. Although the trend of distributions is retained, a dramatic increase on peak stresses is observed by varying the taper ratio from 1/30 to 1/10 (A-3 specimen), and the peak values of shear and peel stresses rise up to 218.0% and 220.8% of the baseline values, respectively. When the thickness of laminate is fixed, the effective lap length of repair reduced due to the increasing of taper ratio. Therefore, a steeper stress gradient occurred in adhesive of larger taper ratio repair. As a result, a proper parameter must be selected on the taper ratio design to avoid the early failure in adhesive caused by severe stress concentration.

Reviewing the results obtained by 3D progressive damage model, the ultimate load of A-3 specimen can achieve 97.0% of the baseline value, and no obvious damage initiation occurs in adhesive before the maximum load. These results indicate that with the taper ratio under 1:10, the adhesive film would keep intact until the ultimate failure of sandwich panel. Therefore, the taper ratio of 1/10 is still acceptable though the stress level is relatively high, and the edgewise compressive behavior of repaired panels would be hardly affected.

In Figure 15(c), the differences between scarf and step repair on stress distribution are investigated. As shown in the figure, similar distribution shape is presented. For step repair, the local stress peaks in each “repair step” occur at the edge of step, while a relatively low stress level is shown in the middle part of step. This phenomenon can be observed most clearly in the “step” lapped by 0° plies. Peak stress values of different repairs are compared in Figure 15(d), the peak value of peel stress is relatively high for step repair, which can achieve the 247.2% of the baseline value, and the peak values of shear stress are almost the same for these two repairs. However, the load-carrying capacity of adhesive is exhibited mainly through shear stress, so the high peak value of peel stress in step repair would not decrease the mechanical performance of adhesive, resulting in little changes on ultimate load of different repaired panels, which has been proved by experiment and 3D finite element model.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The stress distribution is very sensitive to the taper ratio, therefore a proper design parameter must be selected;
The mechanical performance between scarf- and step-repaired panels is almost the same when the diameter of repair region is a constant.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the Key Technology Research Project of Commercial Aircraft Corporation of China, Ltd [grant number SAMC11-JS-07-32].
